answers: gas chromatography [or GC; prompt on chromatography; prompt on gas analysis; prompt on trace vapor analysis] (A TCD is a thermal conductivity detector.)
preconcentrators [accept microfabricated preconcentrators; accept preconcetrator-focuser; accept preconcentrator-injector] (SNL is Sandia National Labs.)
carbon [or C; accept graphitized carbon black]
parts: Name this analytical technique whose detectors include TCDs, which measure the difference in thermal conductivity between the carrier and the effluent.

SNL’s micro hot plate coated with a surfactant-templated sol gel adsorbent was the first of these components for microGC. In conventional GC, these components are heated to inject analyte into the column in a narrow plug.

A graphitized form of this element is the stationary phase in packed microcolumns. Empirical formulae are determined using combustion analysis to measure the relative amounts of oxygen, hydrogen, and this element.

answers: Georges Jacques Danton
Thermidor [accept Thermidorian Reaction; or Réaction thermidorienne; or Coup of Thermidor; prompt on July or August with “please give the month of the French Republican calendar”]
Abbé Sieyès [or Emmanuel Joseph Sieyès]
parts: Name this leader of the Indulgents who was executed alongside his secretary Camille Desmoulins (“day-moo-LAHN”).

Robespierre’s opponents cried “the blood of Danton chokes him!” at his execution during this month. The Directory replaced the Committee of Public Safety with a coup in this month of the French Republican calendar.

After initially refusing to take a position within the Directory, this politician eventually replaced Jean-François Rewbell and established control over the Directory in the Coup of 30 Prairial VII (“seven”). After the establishment of the Consulate, this politician served as second Consul alongside Napoleon and Roger Ducos.

answers: leblouh [prompt on gavage]
corsets [accept whalebone corsets; accept hourglass corset]
teeth [accept smile; accept specific types of teeth such as canines]
parts: Name this inhumane practice in which young girls are repeatedly force-fed camel’s milk and millet until obese, purportedly to improve their desireability among men of marrying age. Following a 2008 coup, this practice saw a resurgence in Mauritania, where it affects as many as 75 percent of women in rural areas.
In Victorian England, whalebone was typically used to produce these waist-tightening garments, which often induced organ damage and rib cage deformation in their mostly female wearers.

Prior to its 1870 ban, the practice of ohaguro saw many Japanese women use an acidic iron-based mixture to dye this body part black. Various unhealthy surgeries involving this body part are central to the modern Japanese trend of yaeba.

answers: near death experiences [accept NDEs; accept answers like almost dying but coming back to life; prompt on dying or death]
neurotheology [accept neuroscience of religion; accept spiritual neuroscience; prompt on neuroscience]
Heaven is for Real: A Little Boy’s Astounding Story of His Trip to Heaven and Back
parts: Name or describe these experiences in which people often report seeing a light at the end of a dark tunnel or see an accelerated series of flashbacks of their life. These often spiritual experiences frequently occur during surgeries.

Near death experiences are often studied in this field of inquiry, which uses observable brain data to answer questions about spiritual or religious experiences. Andrew Newberg’s work in this field has found that religious contemplation coincides with unique brain states.

This book by Todd Burpo relates the story of a four-year-old Nebraskan boy who had a near death experience in which he met his miscarried sister and was able to view his parents during an out of body episode.

answers: the General [or el general; or Zacarías; accept the Patriarch or el patriarca; accept the dictator from The Autumn of the Patriarch; accept el dictador from El otoño del patriarca]
Gabriel García Márquez
chicken coop [or gallinero; accept hen house or any type of structure for chickens]
parts: Name this extremely elderly title character who is obsessed with the beauty queen Leticia Nazareno. Several versions of his death appear at the beginning of each of the six stream of consciousness sections of a 1975 novel about his rule.
The Autumn of the Patriarch is an archetypal Latin American dictator novel by this author, who also wrote Love in the Time of Cholera.

In a disturbing scene from The Autumn of the Patriarch, the General rapes a mulatto servant girl in one of these buildings. In a García Márquez short story, a very old man with enormous wings is imprisoned in one of these structures before it collapses.

answers: Nan Madol
Yap
breadfruit [or dugdug; or tipolo; accept breadnut]
parts: Name this UNESCO World Heritage site located on the island of Pohnpei in the Federated States of Micronesia. This “Venice of the Pacific” consists of buildings atop a series of artificial islands joined by canals.

Another example of megalithic stonework in Micronesia is the heavy, doughnut-shaped, calcite Rai stones used as currency on this island. The master navigator Mau Piailug (“pee-EYE-lug”) was born on Satawal in the Micronesian state named for this larger island.

Commoners living in Nan Madol paid tribute to the chieftain in this fruit, a South Pacific staple food. The HMS Bounty was on an expedition to gather this starchy cousin of the jackfruit when its famous mutiny happened.

answers: King Marke (“MAR-kuh”)
Tristan und Isolde [or Tristan and Isolde]
bass clarinet [reject “clarinet”]
parts: Name this bass operatic charter who sings “Tot denn alles” over the body of his “truest friend.” This character earlier discovers a tryst at daybreak with the assistance of Melot.
King Marke appears in this Richard Wagner opera, which focuses on the potion-induced love between a Cornish hero and a captive Irish Princess.

The leitmotif for “Marke’s Grief,” a descending minor key melody that plays in between Marke’s first lines in Act II, is played by this instrument. This instrument plays a solo during the Act IV marriage scene of Meyerbeer’s Les Huguenots.

answers: The Shadow-Line
Joseph Conrad [or Józef Teodor Konrad Korzeniowski]
“Youth”
parts: Name this 1915 novella in which the narrator abruptly quits his position aboard “an Eastern ship” and returns to London before immediately taking command of a ghastly disease-ridden ship.

The Shadow-Line was written by this Polish-British author. Jameson notes that a central theme of his work is the historical material implications of the transition from sailing ships to steam ships, particularly in Heart of Darkness.

Jameson states that “the experience of being looked at is profoundly ontological” after quoting a passage from this Conrad story. This story describes Charles Marlow’s first journey to Asia aboard the Judea.

answers: indistinguishable [or identical; or indiscernible]
natural log [accept ln]

replace a sum with an integral [accept approximating a sum with an integral; accept any descriptions indicating that a summation is being changed to an integral; accept word forms of integral like integrate or integration; accept word forms or descriptions of sum like summing or addition; prompt on integration alone]
parts: Name this property. In quantum mechanical systems of particles with this property, the exchange operator leaves the Hamiltonian unchanged.

The Sackur–Tetrode entropy is obtained from a derivative of this function of the partition function, a common theme in statistical mechanics. Boltzmann’s equation relates entropy to this function of the number of microstates.

Another common theme in stat mech is performing this mathematical action when calculating partition functions. The validity of this action relies upon the fact that each state occupies a very small phase space volume.

answers: mirror box [prompt on mirrors]
phantom limb syndrome [accept phantom limb pain]
antidepressants [accept tricyclic antidepressants; prompt on TCAs]
parts: Name this type of apparatus developed by V. S. Ramachandran to alleviate neuropathic pain in the missing limbs of amputees.
Mirror box therapy is a common treatment for the pain resulting from this “syndrome,” in which amputees feel pain or discomfort in their missing limb.

Pharmacological treatment of phantom pain often involves a mix of sodium channel blockers and the tricyclic type of these drugs, such as Amitriptyline. MAOIs are most commonly used as this type of drug.

answers: Young People’s Concerts
Gustav Mahler
Carl Ruggles [or Charles Sprague Ruggles]
parts: Tilson Thomas’s classical music PBS series Keeping Score has been compared to this educational TV series. Leonard Bernstein hosted this CBS program from 1958 to 1972, dedicating episodes to Ives and Hindemith.
Tilson Thomas is a leading interpreter of this Austrian Romantic composer who wrote symphonies nicknamed “Titan,” “Resurrection,” and “Symphony of a Thousand.”

Tilson Thomas is the primary champion of this hypermodernist American composer and recorded his brief Complete Works with the Buffalo Symphony Orchestra. That recording features several examples of this composer’s “dissonant counterpoint” style, such as his pieces Evocations and Sun-treader.

answers: nature study movement [accept “study nature, not books”]
Rachel Carson [or Rachel Louise Carson]
National Audubon Society
parts: Name this pedagogical movement that attempted to reconcile scientific knowledge with personal, emotional connections with the environment and de-emphasized book learning in favor of encounters with tangible objects. It was championed by Louis Agassiz and Liberty Hyde Bailey.
Kevin Armitage’s book on the nature study movement notes its influence on this later conservationist, who wrote about DDT’s adverse effects on bird eggs in Silent Spring.

Another proponent of the nature study movement, Mabel Osgood Wright, was also an early leader of this institution. Along with a lab at Cornell, this institution organizes a yearly “census” on Christmas Day in a widely-cited recurring instance of citizen science.

answers: orphanages [or children’s homes; prompt on care homes; reject “foster homes”]
tourism [accept voluntourism or ecotourism]

2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami [or 2004 Asian earthquake and tsunami; or Boxing Day Tsunami; or Sumatra-Andaman earthquake; accept December 26th earthquake and tsunami; prompt on answers mentioning an Indian Ocean or Asian tsunami or earthquake by stating “either give the year or the date it occurred.”]
parts: Name these institutions. In the early 1990s, the 20/20 program “Shame of a Nation” called attention to the horrible state of these institutions in Romania.

Some developing countries keep their orphanages running so that children can be saved by people doing the “volunteer” form of this activity. The oxymoronic “eco” form of this activity might involve visiting the Galápagos Islands.

Maestral International found that 97% of the children brought to orphanages in Indonesia following this event were not orphans, but instead were sent by parents in hopes of getting better educations. The DART system was greatly expanded following this event to reduce the damage from future such events.

answers: Hadrian [or Hadrien; or accept Caesar Traianus Hadrianus; accept Memoirs of Hadrian or Mémoires d’Hadrien; accept Emperor Hadrian] (Memoirs of Hadrian is by Marguerite Yourcenar, and the poem in the lead-in is “Animula, vagula, blandula.”)
Claudius [or Tiberius Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus; accept I, Claudius]
John Williams (The unnamed novel is Stoner.)
parts: Name this elderly narrator of a French novel framed as a reflective epistle to his grandson, who he addresses with the nickname “Mark.”
This Roman emperor ascends to power despite his stammer and meek demeanor in a Robert Graves novel framed as his autobiography.

Only the last few of the letters that comprise this author’s novel Augustus are written by Octavian. Anna Gavalda’s 2011 French translation of a 1965 novel by this author about a University of Missouri English professor helped make it a surprise best-seller in Europe.

answers: sick role
structural functionalism [accept word forms; accept structuralism or word forms]
psychological stress [accept biological stress; accept stress; accept Holmes and Rahe stress scale]
parts: Give this two word term from medical sociology coined by Talcott Parsons to refer to people deemed to possess a “sanctioned deviance” by medical professionals.

Relations of individuals in sick roles with society at large are analyzed in this broad sociological framework that views society as a complex mechanism that leads to stability. This social approach is usually contrasted with conflict theory and symbolic interactionism.

Mechanic and Volkhart’s illness behavior model suggest that higher levels of this variable in individuals make them more readily adopt the sick role. The death of a spouse and divorce are among the highest inducers of this phenomenon in a scale developed by Holmes and Rahe.

answers: thirteen [accept Friday the Thirteenth]
seventeen (The Latin word is “vixi.”)
three
parts: Give this two digit number, considered unlucky in many Western superstitions. Thomas W. Lawson’s novel about a stock market manipulator is likely the origin of a superstition about Fridays that land on this date.

In Italy, this number holds a similar superstitious position as thirteen in the US. The superstition surrounding this number derives from the fact that the Roman numeral spelling of this number can be rearranged to spell the Latin word for “I have lived,” or “My life is over.”
Prohibitions stemming from nighttime activity in the trenches of World War I may be the origin of the superstition that lighting this many cigarettes with one match is unlucky.

answers: Baghdad
Nasir al-Din al-Tusi [or Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn al-Hasan al-Tūsī; accept Tusi couple]
optics [accept Book of Optics; prompt on physics]
parts: Name this Abbasid capital city where astronomers worked in the House of Wisdom.

This 13th-century Persian astronomer was the first to correctly hypothesize that the Milky Way was made up of a mass of densely packed stars. This polymath critiqued the notion of circular planetary motion by using his namesake couple.

Another medieval Muslim astronomer, Ibn Al-Haytham, has been called the father of this scientific discipline for his Kitab al-Manazir. Along with the Almagest and the Geography, this discipline titles one of the three scientific texts by Ptolemy widely studied by Muslim scholars.

answers: Porphyry of Tyre [accept Porphyrian tree]
Neoplatonism [accept word forms; prompt on Platonism]
differentia [prompt on diaphora by asking “what is the Latin term?”]
parts: Name this logician who wrote the Isagoge and edited his teacher’s writings into the Enneads.
Porphyry and his teacher Plotinus were exponents of this school of philosophy that sought to further develop the thought of the ancient Greek author who wrote the Symposium.

The terms on the outer edges of a Porphyrian tree are referred to by this Latin term, which are descriptions that characterize a species inside its genus. For the species human in the genus animal, this thing might be “having the ability to reason.”

answers: noon
bells [accept “The Bells”] (The Dickinson poem is number 498.)
bees [accept “Telling the Bees”]
parts: Name this word, supposedly the favorite word of Emily Dickinson because of its symmetry and the hollowness in its middle. This word names an annual collection of avant garde feminist writings edited by Diane Williams in homage to Dickinson’s frequent use of it.

The speaker wishes to “be Noon to Him” in a Dickinson poem in which the sound of some of these objects “tell him that it is Noon abroad.” Edgar Allen Poe coined the term “tintinnabulation” in a poem titled for these things.

In Dickinson’s poem “The Soul has Bandaged moments,” a “prowling” one of these animals “[Touches] Liberty - then knows no more - / But Noon, and Paradise.” A John Greenleaf Whittier poem titled for these creatures references a folk custom in which they must be informed of major human life events to have good luck.

answers: synapses
m-cubed times h [or m-to-the-third times h; or m3h; accept answers in either order since multiplication is commutative]
resting membrane potential
parts: Name these junctions between one neuron’s dendrites and another neuron’s axon.

Sodium’s conductance, which rapidly increases, and then rapidly decreases during an action potential, is proportional to this expression of m and h in the Hodgkin–Huxley model. Give your answer as a function of m and h, keeping in mind that m and h are the probabilities that activation and inactivation gates are open, respectively.

During depolarization, the membrane potential increases away from this value, which is about negative 70 millivolts in a typical neuron. This is the value of the membrane potential when a neuron is inactive.

answers: Amsterdam Town Hall [or Koninklijk Paleis van Amsterdam; accept the New Town Hall of Amsterdam; accept Royal Palace of Amsterdam; accept Paleis op de Dam; prompt on just Town Hall or Royal Palace by asking “of what city?”]
Rembrandt van Rijn [or Rembrandt Harmenszoon van Rijn]
Pieter de Hooch (“hoh”)
parts: Name this building whose Burgomaster’s chamber contains Ferdinand Bol’s Fabritius and Pyrrhus. This building also contains a series of lunette history paintings on the subject of the Batavian Revolt.

This Dutch painter’s Conspiracy of Claudius Civilis was removed from the Amsterdam Town Hall, likely for clashing with the style of the other paintings in the building. He also painted The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp.

This other Dutch Golden Age painter depicted a red curtain and a small assembly in his painting The Council Chamber in Amsterdam Town Hall. This genre painter is known for serene domestic scenes featuring open doors, like in his The Little Street in Delft.

answers: vertex cover problem [accept descriptions of finding the minimum vertex cover; prompt on cover; prompt on set cover]
NP [accept NP-complete; accept NP-hard]
parameterized complexity (FPT is fixed-parameter tractable.)
parts: Name this problem whose solution set must contain at least one endpoint of each edge in the underlying graph.

The vertex cover problem is one of Richard Karp’s 21 of the hardest problems in this complexity class. A famous open problem asks if this class is equivalent to the class of decision problems solvable in polynomial time.

Letting k be the vertex cover size and n be the graph size, this branch of complexity theory places vertex cover in class FPT because it runs in big-O of “some function of k times some polynomial of n.” This branch of complexity theory fixes an input variable to see if some instances of NP problems can be solved efficiently.
